utterances: I am not the greatest pianist in the world.
There certainly are greater virtuosos than I.
(Singing) I'll be seeing you in all the old familiar places...
Liberace was the first megastar in Vegas.
When he opened at the Riviera Hotel in 1955, he was the highest-paid performer, earning $50,000 a week.
Until his death in 1987, he was Vegas' top draw.
Legions of fans came to see him in his jewel-encrusted outfits.
The most flamboyant cost $750,000.
That costume has 40,000 Swarovski crystals, two and a half carats each.
Christine Phillips is one of the tour guides at the museum.
They are all elderly women who adore Liberace without a trace of irony.
And this costume used to be very ice-blue.
It's faded a lot.
And we call this BC; that was before capes.
We have three costumes that are BC.
Now he has a big cape that is very heavy, but it's being cleaned.
But this was actually made before the capes.
Do you think Las Vegas is remembering him, remembering him properly?
Oh, there's not enough, no. They're too much into the stars today.
And most people, young people, don't know what he--who he was; Liberace (pronounced lee-bur-AYSS), they say.
But you know, one day about a year ago, we got one guy who was a black hip-hop kid.
He came in this museum because he thought it was a casino, and we took him by the hand and made him see the museum, and he loved it.
He loved it.
So we said, `Go tell your friends so your generation can know who it is, too.'
The Queen of Bling.
The King,"" though, is alive and well.
Downtown at the decidedly unglitzy Plaza Hotel, Elvis performs four days a week.
I've been performing as Elvis about eight years full-time, maybe nine, and originally started about 12 years ago.
That's Johnny Thompson.
He's dyed his blond hair back and wears mascara and a white jumpsuit called the `aloha from Hawaii' jumpsuit.
That's the Elvis with the sideburns, big sunglasses, the past-his-prime Elvis.

Well, originally when I came to the Plaza, they were talking about putting me in the showroom, and since then, they've had a change of plans, so I'm still hoping to go in there one day, but if not, this is the lounge.
Oh.
This lounge here is the Omaha Lounge.
Right.
Right.
I mean, this is the first time I've ever played the lounge.
I mean, I've really headlined in concerts and I've played NFL games where, you know, there was a hundred thousand people.
And this is the first time I've done something like this.
Can you give us a little sample?
(Singing) Love me tender, love me sweet, never let me go.
You have made my life complete and I love you so.
Was that good?
That was Elvis.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
Downtown may still love ""The King,"" but the Strip has moved on.
The $2.7 billion Wynn Hotel has just opened--oh, and it's also a casino, but that seems like an afterthought.
Last year in Vegas, tourists spent more money on shows, food and shopping than on gambling.
So when you enter the Wynn, the first thing you see is upscale boutiques: Chanel, Christian Dior and Jean-Paul Gauthier.
The theme of the Wynn is luxury.
That's the new buzzword in Las Vegas is luxury.
Theme is, like, '90s, you know.
It's like we're not going to say themed environment anymore; luxurious environment.
It's--you know, we're richer, we're bitcher.
(Laughs)
And Charles Phoenix, expert on all things Vegas with a V, takes one look at the imported hydroponic forest in front of the Wynn and pronounces the one takeaway image is this.
Palm trees are out; pine trees are in.
(Laughs)
Wait, am I right or wrong?
Look over there.
You're so right.
Do you see that?
It's all pine trees.
It's pine trees, pine trees.
How fresh!
In other words, Vegas is remaining true to its past in one enduring way: It is still decadent.
Happy birthday, Las Vegas.
Madeleine Brand, NPR News.
(Soundbite of song)
(Singing) ...at the moon, but I'll be seeing you.
That report produced by Shereen Meraji.
For pictures of Madeleine's adventures in Vegas--Shereen took them--visit our Web site, npr.org.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
More DAY TO DAY just ahead.
From NPR News, this is TALK OF THE NATION/SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Joe Palca.
Up next, a progress report on a federal program created to bolster US defenses against bioterrorism.
Project Bioshield was signed into law--I guess it was last July by President Bush.
Its mandate is to boost research into new drugs and vaccines against bioterror agents and then to buy those drugs for our national stockpile once they're developed.
Well, we're one year out and--How are things doing?
Is our national stockpile well-fortified?
Do we have a plan for meeting any biothreat that comes our way?
That's what we'll be talking about for the rest of this hour so if you'd like to join our discussion, give us a call.
Our number is (800) 989-8255.
That's (800) 989-TALK.

If you want more information about what we'll talking about this hour, go to our Web site at www.sciencefriday.com where we've assembled a set of links to what we'll be talking about, which is Project Bioshield.
Now let me introduce my guest.
William Raub is the deputy assistant secretary for Public Health Emergency Preparedness in the Department of Health and Human Services, or HHS, as we love to say here in acronym-crazy Washington.
He joins me in his office there.
Welcome to the program, Dr. Raub.
Thank you very much, Mr. Palca.
I appreciate the opportunity to join you.
Well, it's nice to talk to you again.
We used to speak quite frequently when you were at the National Institutes of Health, I seem to recall.
Yes, indeed.
It's been a long time.
It has.
We're one year in.
You just gave a progress report to Congress about Project Bioshield.
What did you tell them?

I was wondering--I was--the rumors in recent report from--I think it was the National Academy of Sciences--basically talking about the threats of the milk supply, and I was wondering--part of that report basically talked about, if I remember correctly, the shortage we have of ventilators in the country, and I was wondering basically if there's any efforts made to stockpile ventilators at the moment and not just addressing, for example, botulism, but a number of other, you know, respiratory diseases that could possibly be used to attack us.
So I'll take my question off the air.
OK.
Justin, thanks for that call.
Ventilators, Dr. Raub.

Well, I don't want to dwell on this, but I thought that your office's position had been that actually your leadership political action committee did help to pay your lawyers bills, but that you believe that was a legitimate use of money.
Is that correct?
Kahn and other Jewish leaders registered their concerns with museum officials who apparently agreed.
Two weeks ago, Barbara Lubin got a phone call from museum officials saying the show, which had been approved and was scheduled to open today, would in fact be cancelled.
We were really, really shocked.
Shocked, in part, says Lubin, because seven years ago the museum showed a similar exhibit of art from Iraqi children.
MOCHA officials were unavailable for an interview.
The museum has been caught off guard by the controversy.
It is typically a place where parents can leave their kids to finger-paint and enjoy arts education classes.
